elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Solid-state conversion of three-dimensional K<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> coordination polymer [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) nanostructures, [1,5-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>nds = 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid], prepared by sonochemical procedure, to three-dimensional [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) coordination polymer nanoparticles was studied by mechanochemical reaction. During this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> and coordination sphere of metal ion in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> changed from <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and <ce:bold>K</ce:bold>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> to <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>Tl</ce:bold>⋯Tl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. IR spectroscopy, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and thermo gravimetric and differantial thermal analyses (TG-DTA), indicated that this conversion is irreversible.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Solid-state conversion of three-dimensional KI coordination polymer [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) nanostructures, [1,5-H2nds=1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid], prepared by sonochemical procedure, to three-dimensional [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2) coordination polymer nanoparticles was studied by mechanochemical reaction. During this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from 1, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds2 ¯ and coordination sphere of metal ion in 1 changed from μ  8 - and KO8 to μ  12 - and O9 Tl⋯Tl3 in 2, respectively. IR spectroscopy, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and thermo gravimetric and differantial thermal analyses (TG-DTA), indicated that this conversion is irreversible.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of potassium(I) CP nanostructure, prepared by sonochemical procedure, to thallium(I) CP nanostructures has been studied. This conversion is irreversible. The metal ion in thallium CP is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions and against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive’ in the solid-state.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:alt-text id="al0025" role="short">Unlabelled Image</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0025" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S1387700318302132/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of potassium(I) CP nanostructure, prepared by sonochemical procedure, to thallium(I) CP nanostructures has been studied. This conversion is irreversible. The metal ion in thallium CP is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions and against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive' in the solid-state.  Unlabelled Image

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:alt-text id="al0025" role="short">Unlabelled Image</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0025" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S1387700318302132/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="li0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">K coordination polymer nanostructure was synthesized by sonochemical procedure.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of it to Tl(I) CP nanoparticles was studied.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">IR, XRD and TG-DTA analyses, indicated that this conversion is irreversible.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The thallium is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0025">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive’ in the solid-state.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ K coordination polymer nanostructure was synthesized by sonochemical procedure.   ⋅ Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of it to Tl(I) CP nanoparticles was studied.   ⋅ IR, XRD and TG-DTA analyses, indicated that this conversion is irreversible.   ⋅ The thallium is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions.   ⋅ The lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive' in the solid-state.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">K coordination polymer nanostructure was synthesized by sonochemical procedure.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of it to Tl(I) CP nanoparticles was studied.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">IR, XRD and TG-DTA analyses, indicated that this conversion is irreversible.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The thallium is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive’ in the solid-state.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Modern concepts of crystal engineering enable the prediction of the solid state phase of most coordination polymers from the knowledge of the preferred coordination geometries of the metal centers, strength of the interactions of the metal centers with the donor atoms and groups present in the compound, and simple arithmetic calculations []. One of the fundamental aspects of modulating the properties of coordination polymers is to control their structure architectures, which is directly influenced by the judicious choice and self-assembly process involving metal ions and organic linker []. In contrast to coordination polymers of transition metal ions, the formation of polymers with thallium ion is disproportionately sparse []. Thallium has attracted special interest in recent years due to its pronounced ability to cause metallophilic interactions []. The Tl<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion may be nonspherical and hemidirected, with its inert pair (6s<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) partially hybridized leading to the formation of a local dipole that may strongly affect cation⋯ligand interactions or spherical and holodirected with inactive 6s<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> electron lone pair []. Thallium(I) usually favors the formation of Tl⋯Tl, Tl⋯C, Tl⋯H secondary interactions especially on its vacant coordination sphere with the stereochemically active lone pair, which indicates that thallium(I) ions reflect the capacity to act as both a Lewis acid and a Lewis base []. Especially with unsaturated carbon atoms, it forms organometallic polymers []. Thallium(I) usually forms neutral species and exhibits greater tendency to form one-dimensional supramolecular compounds []. Mechanosynthesis has a significant potential, as it offers short reaction times and avoids large quantities of solvent []. Polygons and very recently, porous MOFs from metal salts were synthesized via neat (solvent-free) grinding method []. Manipulation of the coordination sphere by mechanical means is an exciting yet rarely explored alternative which may upon novel avenues in coordination chemistry and catalyst []. Reversibility of the coordinative interactions could then result in the continuous reformation of polymer chains until a steady-state degree of polymerization is reached [,]. Irreversible disruption of covalent bonds is known to occur in polymers subject to strong shear forces [] and it is the basis of some processing technologies, such as the mastication of natural rubber. In this work, we would like to study solid-state mechanochemical conversion of nanostructured [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), (1,5-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>nds = 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid) coordination polymer [] to [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), also the reversibility of this solid-state conversion was studied. Since thallium might be regarded as a relativistic alkali metal because Tl chemistry parallels that of the alkali metals in many ways [] and the well-known toxicity of thallium compounds may also be associated with non-reversibility of the complexation reactions as compared to the action of potassium cations [], we decided to study the structural changes of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> during conversion of it to Tl(I) complex of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) by mechanochemical reaction of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
K coordination polymer nanostructure was synthesized by sonochemical procedure.

Solid-state mechanochemical conversion of it to Tl(I) CP nanoparticles was studied.

IR, XRD and TG-DTA analyses, indicated that this conversion is irreversible.

The thallium is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions.

The lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive' in the solid-state.

Modern concepts of crystal engineering enable the prediction of the solid state phase of most coordination polymers from the knowledge of the preferred coordination geometries of the metal centers, strength of the interactions of the metal centers with the donor atoms and groups present in the compound, and simple arithmetic calculations []. One of the fundamental aspects of modulating the properties of coordination polymers is to control their structure architectures, which is directly influenced by the judicious choice and self-assembly process involving metal ions and organic linker []. In contrast to coordination polymers of transition metal ions, the formation of polymers with thallium ion is disproportionately sparse []. Thallium has attracted special interest in recent years due to its pronounced ability to cause metallophilic interactions []. The Tl+ ion may be nonspherical and hemidirected, with its inert pair (6s2) partially hybridized leading to the formation of a local dipole that may strongly affect cation⋯ligand interactions or spherical and holodirected with inactive 6s2 electron lone pair []. Thallium(I) usually favors the formation of Tl⋯Tl, Tl⋯C, Tl⋯H secondary interactions especially on its vacant coordination sphere with the stereochemically active lone pair, which indicates that thallium(I) ions reflect the capacity to act as both a Lewis acid and a Lewis base []. Especially with unsaturated carbon atoms, it forms organometallic polymers []. Thallium(I) usually forms neutral species and exhibits greater tendency to form one-dimensional supramolecular compounds []. Mechanosynthesis has a significant potential, as it offers short reaction times and avoids large quantities of solvent []. Polygons and very recently, porous MOFs from metal salts were synthesized via neat (solvent-free) grinding method []. Manipulation of the coordination sphere by mechanical means is an exciting yet rarely explored alternative which may upon novel avenues in coordination chemistry and catalyst []. Reversibility of the coordinative interactions could then result in the continuous reformation of polymer chains until a steady-state degree of polymerization is reached [,]. Irreversible disruption of covalent bonds is known to occur in polymers subject to strong shear forces [] and it is the basis of some processing technologies, such as the mastication of natural rubber. In this work, we would like to study solid-state mechanochemical conversion of nanostructured [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1), (1,5-H2nds=1,5-naphthalenedisulfonic acid) coordination polymer [] to [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2), also the reversibility of this solid-state conversion was studied. Since thallium might be regarded as a relativistic alkali metal because Tl chemistry parallels that of the alkali metals in many ways [] and the well-known toxicity of thallium compounds may also be associated with non-reversibility of the complexation reactions as compared to the action of potassium cations [], we decided to study the structural changes of 1 during conversion of it to Tl(I) complex of 1,5-nds2 ¯ (2) by mechanochemical reaction of 1 with excess TlNO3.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The reaction between 1,5-Naphthalenedisulfonic acid and KOH in ultrasonic bath results in formation of white powder which was dried at room temperature. A comparison between the XRD patterns simulated from single crystal X-ray data of [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) [] (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>) and that of the prepared powder (b), approved the formation of it. a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor> shows that 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> acts as a bridging ligand between eight potassium ions. Only one type of potassium ion exists in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which is coordinated with five oxygen atoms from sulfonate groups of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> ligands and three oxygen atoms from three water molecules (b). The water molecules in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> bridge between three potassium ions and finally we have three dimensional coordination polymer in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor> top). SEM image of the obtained powder approved that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> nanostructures were formed under ultrasonic irradiations (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The XRD pattern of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (c) approved that ion exchange process of K(I) with Tl(I) was occurred. After removal of KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and unreacted TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> from the products mixture, the pure phase of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (d) was separated. SEM image of the mixture obtained from mechanochemical reaction of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> indicated the formation of nanoparticles (b) with different morphology to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (a). After washing the prepared mixture with water, pure phase of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology was seen (c). A comparison between the XRD patterns simulated from single crystal X-ray data of Tl(I) complex of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (e) and that of the prepared agglomerated nanoparticles (d), approved that the prepared nanoparticles have the same structure as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. It should be noted that some differences between the peak intensity of simulated and experimental patterns is depending on textural features such as preferred orientations of nanocrystaline samples. Thus our attempts for synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> from mechanochemical reaction of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is successful. In order to study the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in detail, a reaction was done between 1,5-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>nds and TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> which provided crystalline materials (Table S1 in the SI) of the general formula [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). c shows the primary structural building unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. It shows that 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> acts as a bridging ligand between twelve thallium ions. Only one type of thallium ion exists in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> which is coordinated with nine oxygen atoms from sulfonate groups of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> ligands (d). In addition to Tl<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O coordination bonds in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the thallium ion involves in three thallophilic secondary interactions with Tl⋯Tl distances of 3.6451(5), 3.6451(5) and 3.6797(9) Å (Table S2 in the SI) which are lower than the sum of the vander Waals radii of two Tl atoms (4.0 Å) []. Thus we could consider O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>Tl</ce:bold>⋯Tl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination sphere around it (d). Against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds [], in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive’ in the solid-state and the arrangement of O-atoms do not suggest a gap or hole in coordination geometry around the Tl(I) coordination sphere (d). Our search also shows that Tl in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> does not involve in Tl⋯C, Tl⋯H or any π-π interactions. Finally it seems that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a three-dimensional coordination polymer ( down).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The reaction between 1,5-Naphthalenedisulfonic acid and KOH in ultrasonic bath results in formation of white powder which was dried at room temperature. A comparison between the XRD patterns simulated from single crystal X-ray data of [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) [] (a) and that of the prepared powder (b), approved the formation of it. a shows that 1,5-nds2 ¯ acts as a bridging ligand between eight potassium ions. Only one type of potassium ion exists in 1 which is coordinated with five oxygen atoms from sulfonate groups of 1,5-nds2 ¯ ligands and three oxygen atoms from three water molecules (b). The water molecules in 1 bridge between three potassium ions and finally we have three dimensional coordination polymer in 1 (  top). SEM image of the obtained powder approved that compound 1 nanostructures were formed under ultrasonic irradiations (a). The XRD pattern of compound 1 after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO3 (c) approved that ion exchange process of K(I) with Tl(I) was occurred. After removal of KNO3 and unreacted TlNO3 from the products mixture, the pure phase of 2 (d) was separated. SEM image of the mixture obtained from mechanochemical reaction of 1 with excess TlNO3 indicated the formation of nanoparticles (b) with different morphology to 1 (a). After washing the prepared mixture with water, pure phase of compound 2 with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology was seen (c). A comparison between the XRD patterns simulated from single crystal X-ray data of Tl(I) complex of 1,5-nds2 ¯ (2) (e) and that of the prepared agglomerated nanoparticles (d), approved that the prepared nanoparticles have the same structure as 2. It should be noted that some differences between the peak intensity of simulated and experimental patterns is depending on textural features such as preferred orientations of nanocrystaline samples. Thus our attempts for synthesis of 2 from mechanochemical reaction of 1 with excess TlNO3 is successful. In order to study the structure of 2 in detail, a reaction was done between 1,5-H2nds and TlNO3 which provided crystalline materials (Table S1 in the SI) of the general formula [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2). c shows the primary structural building unit of 2. It shows that 1,5-nds2 ¯ acts as a bridging ligand between twelve thallium ions. Only one type of thallium ion exists in 2 which is coordinated with nine oxygen atoms from sulfonate groups of 1,5-nds2 ¯ ligands (d). In addition to TlO coordination bonds in 2, the thallium ion involves in three thallophilic secondary interactions with Tl⋯Tl distances of 3.6451(5), 3.6451(5) and 3.6797(9) Å (Table S2 in the SI) which are lower than the sum of the vander Waals radii of two Tl atoms (4.0Å) []. Thus we could consider O9 Tl⋯Tl3 coordination sphere around it (d). Against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds [], in compound 2, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive' in the solid-state and the arrangement of O-atoms do not suggest a gap or hole in coordination geometry around the Tl(I) coordination sphere (d). Our search also shows that Tl in compound 2 does not involve in Tl⋯C, Tl⋯H or any π-π interactions. Finally it seems that compound 2 is a three-dimensional coordination polymer ( down).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The XRD pattern of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after mechanochemical reaction of it with KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (f) is similar to that observed in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after mechanochemical reaction of it with TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (c). Thus in this stage we have mixture of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and this transformation is irreversible. The SEM image of the prepared sample from the reverse reaction indicates the existence of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> nanoparticles (d). Thus its morphology does not change after grinding of it with excess KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. The XRD pattern of the sample prepared from the reverse reaction after washing with water (g) indicates the existence of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with nanorod morphology (e). A comparison between the coordination geometry of the K and Tl atoms in the coordination polymers of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows that during this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) coordination polymer, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> and coordination sphere of metal ion in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> changed from <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and <ce:bold>K</ce:bold>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> to <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>Tl</ce:bold>⋯Tl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), respectively. Recently, solid-state conversion of [Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> to [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> was studied by cation exchange mechanochemical reaction. Against to what observed about compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, this conversion was reversible and their nanostructures were also converted to each other reversibly [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The XRD pattern of 2 after mechanochemical reaction of it with KNO3 (f) is similar to that observed in compound 1 after mechanochemical reaction of it with TlNO3 (c). Thus in this stage we have mixture of 2 and KNO3 and this transformation is irreversible. The SEM image of the prepared sample from the reverse reaction indicates the existence of compound 2 nanoparticles (d). Thus its morphology does not change after grinding of it with excess KNO3. The XRD pattern of the sample prepared from the reverse reaction after washing with water (g) indicates the existence of compound 2 with nanorod morphology (e). A comparison between the coordination geometry of the K and Tl atoms in the coordination polymers of 1 and 2 shows that during this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) coordination polymer, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds2 ¯ and coordination sphere of metal ion in 1 changed from μ  8 - and KO8 to μ  12 - and O9 Tl⋯Tl3 in [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2), respectively. Recently, solid-state conversion of [Na2(1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n to [Ag2(1,5-nds)]n was studied by cation exchange mechanochemical reaction. Against to what observed about compounds 1 and 2, this conversion was reversible and their nanostructures were also converted to each other reversibly [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">To further confirm of this irreversible solid-state reaction, IR spectra were recorded for all of five samples prepared during these conversion in addition to IR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S1 in the SI). The IR spectrum of prepared powder of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> under ultrasonic irradiation (Fig. S1a in the SI) shows characteristic absorption bands for the 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> ligand. The absorption bands with variable intensity in the frequency range 1000–1400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 700 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> correspond to various symmetric and asymmetric vibrations of two <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">¯</ce:sup> groups of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> ligand. Ring vibrations of the 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> aromatic ring appear in the frequency range of 1400–1600 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. A comparison between the IR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> synthesized by sonochemical process (Fig. S1a in the SI) and compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S1b in the SI) showed that there is no difference between them but after washing the mixture and removal of KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and unreacted TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> from the products mixture, specific IR spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained (Fig. S1c in the SI) which is similar to pure phase of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> prepared as single crystals of it from another reaction (Fig. S1d in the SI). In IR spectrum of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after liquid-assisted mechanochemical reaction with KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S1e in the SI) in addition to characteristic absorption bands for the 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> ligand, a new band at 1370 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (vs) was appeared which is due to existence of unreacted KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. IR spectrum of the sample after removal of unreacted KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> from the products mixture (Fig. S1f in the SI) is exactly the same as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> nanostructure (Fig. S1c in the SI) approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To further confirm of this irreversible solid-state reaction, IR spectra were recorded for all of five samples prepared during these conversion in addition to IR spectrum of compound 2 (Fig. S1 in the SI). The IR spectrum of prepared powder of 1 under ultrasonic irradiation (Fig. S1a in the SI) shows characteristic absorption bands for the 1,5-nds2 ¯ ligand. The absorption bands with variable intensity in the frequency range 1000-1400cm-1 and 700cm-1 correspond to various symmetric and asymmetric vibrations of two SO3 ¯ groups of 1,5-nds2 ¯ ligand. Ring vibrations of the 1,5-nds2 ¯ aromatic ring appear in the frequency range of 1400-1600cm-1. A comparison between the IR spectrum of compound 1 synthesized by sonochemical process (Fig. S1a in the SI) and compound 1 after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO3 (Fig. S1b in the SI) showed that there is no difference between them but after washing the mixture and removal of KNO3 and unreacted TlNO3 from the products mixture, specific IR spectrum of 2 was obtained (Fig. S1c in the SI) which is similar to pure phase of compound 2 prepared as single crystals of it from another reaction (Fig. S1d in the SI). In IR spectrum of compound 2 after liquid-assisted mechanochemical reaction with KNO3 (Fig. S1e in the SI) in addition to characteristic absorption bands for the 1,5-nds2 ¯ ligand, a new band at 1370cm-1 (vs) was appeared which is due to existence of unreacted KNO3. IR spectrum of the sample after removal of unreacted KNO3 from the products mixture (Fig. S1f in the SI) is exactly the same as 2 nanostructure (Fig. S1c in the SI) approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">TGA data (Fig. S2a in the SI) indicates that endothermic removal of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules from [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) nanostructures starts at 32 °C and this process is continued up to 82 °C with a mass loss of 6.8% (calcd 8.9%). The remaining compound is stable up to 500 °C. The thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S2b in the SI) is different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S2a in the SI) which approved formation of other new compound (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) from this conversion. The main component of this mixture (Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is stable up to 360 °C (Fig. S2b in the SI). The thermal behavior of [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) after washing the mixture obtained from solid-state mechanochemical reaction (Fig. S2c in the SI) shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology is stable up to 335 °C. Mass loss between 335 and 410 °C which accompanied with a broad exothermic peak may be attributed to combustion of some organic parts of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S2c in the SI). We also examined thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after mechanochemical reaction of it with excess KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S2d in the SI). The resulting curve was exactly the same as that observed in Fig. S2b (in the SI) which approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible (Fig. S2d in the SI). Fig. S2e (in the SI) also showed that pure phase of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> nanoparticles, which did not react with KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, have similar thermal stability to its other samples obtained from previous steps (Fig. S2b–d in the SI). Thus in addition to powder XRD analyses () and IR spectroscopy (Fig. S1 in the SI), thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TG-DTA) approved that this solid-state mechanochemical exchange is irreversible. The irreversibility of this exchange is due to formation of more stable complex with lower energy in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in comparison with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: TGA data (Fig. S2a in the SI) indicates that endothermic removal of H2O molecules from [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) nanostructures starts at 32°C and this process is continued up to 82°C with a mass loss of 6.8% (calcd 8.9%). The remaining compound is stable up to 500°C. The thermal behavior of compound 1 after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO3 (Fig. S2b in the SI) is different from 1 (Fig. S2a in the SI) which approved formation of other new compound (2) from this conversion. The main component of this mixture (Compound 2) is stable up to 360°C (Fig. S2b in the SI). The thermal behavior of [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2) after washing the mixture obtained from solid-state mechanochemical reaction (Fig. S2c in the SI) shows that compound 2 with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology is stable up to 335°C. Mass loss between 335 and 410°C which accompanied with a broad exothermic peak may be attributed to combustion of some organic parts of 2 (Fig. S2c in the SI). We also examined thermal behavior of compound 2 after mechanochemical reaction of it with excess KNO3 (Fig. S2d in the SI). The resulting curve was exactly the same as that observed in Fig. S2b (in the SI) which approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible (Fig. S2d in the SI). Fig. S2e (in the SI) also showed that pure phase of compound 2 nanoparticles, which did not react with KNO3, have similar thermal stability to its other samples obtained from previous steps (Fig. S2b-d in the SI). Thus in addition to powder XRD analyses () and IR spectroscopy (Fig. S1 in the SI), thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TG-DTA) approved that this solid-state mechanochemical exchange is irreversible. The irreversibility of this exchange is due to formation of more stable complex with lower energy in 2 in comparison with 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, irreversible solid-state structural conversion of three-dimensional K<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> coordination polymer [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) nanostructures synthesized by sonochemical procedure, to three-dimensional [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) coordination polymer nanoparticles has been observed upon mechanochemical reaction of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. This irreversible exchange is similar to that occurred in biological systems approved the toxicity of thallium. The thallium ion in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions and during this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">¯</ce:inf> and coordination sphere of metal ion in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> changed from <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and <ce:bold>K</ce:bold>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> to <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>- and O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>Tl</ce:bold>⋯Tl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. Against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds, in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive’ in the solid-state and the arrangement of O-atoms do not suggest a gap or hole in coordination geometry around the Tl(I) coordination sphere. Studying these types of solid-state mechanochemical reaction is being investigated in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, irreversible solid-state structural conversion of three-dimensional KI coordination polymer [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) nanostructures synthesized by sonochemical procedure, to three-dimensional [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2) coordination polymer nanoparticles has been observed upon mechanochemical reaction of compound 1 with TlNO3. This irreversible exchange is similar to that occurred in biological systems approved the toxicity of thallium. The thallium ion in 2 is involved in three secondary thallophilic interactions and during this solid-state cation exchange process, in addition to removal of two coordinated water molecules from 1, the coordination mode of 1,5-nds2 ¯ and coordination sphere of metal ion in 1 changed from μ  8 - and KO8 to μ  12 - and O9 Tl⋯Tl3 in 2, respectively. Against to those observed in thallium(I) compounds, in compound 2, the lone pair of Tl(I) is ‘inactive' in the solid-state and the arrangement of O-atoms do not suggest a gap or hole in coordination geometry around the Tl(I) coordination sphere. Studying these types of solid-state mechanochemical reaction is being investigated in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">TGA data (Fig. S2a in the SI) indicates that endothermic removal of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules from [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) nanostructures starts at 32 °C and this process is continued up to 82 °C with a mass loss of 6.8% (calcd 8.9%). The remaining compound is stable up to 500 °C. The thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S2b in the SI) is different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S2a in the SI) which approved formation of other new compound (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) from this conversion. The main component of this mixture (Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is stable up to 360 °C (Fig. S2b in the SI). The thermal behavior of [Tl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>12</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–1,5-nds)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) after washing the mixture obtained from solid-state mechanochemical reaction (Fig. S2c in the SI) shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology is stable up to 335 °C. Mass loss between 335 and 410 °C which accompanied with a broad exothermic peak may be attributed to combustion of some organic parts of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S2c in the SI). We also examined thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after mechanochemical reaction of it with excess KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Fig. S2d in the SI). The resulting curve was exactly the same as that observed in Fig. S2b (in the SI) which approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible (Fig. S2d in the SI). Fig. S2e (in the SI) also showed that pure phase of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> nanoparticles, which did not react with KNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, have similar thermal stability to its other samples obtained from previous steps (Fig. S2b–d in the SI). Thus in addition to powder XRD analyses () and IR spectroscopy (Fig. S1 in the SI), thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TG-DTA) approved that this solid-state mechanochemical exchange is irreversible. The irreversibility of this exchange is due to formation of more stable complex with lower energy in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in comparison with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: TGA data (Fig. S2a in the SI) indicates that endothermic removal of H2O molecules from [K2(μ  8 -1,5-nds)(H2O)2]n (1) nanostructures starts at 32°C and this process is continued up to 82°C with a mass loss of 6.8% (calcd 8.9%). The remaining compound is stable up to 500°C. The thermal behavior of compound 1 after solid-state mechanochemical reaction with excess TlNO3 (Fig. S2b in the SI) is different from 1 (Fig. S2a in the SI) which approved formation of other new compound (2) from this conversion. The main component of this mixture (Compound 2) is stable up to 360°C (Fig. S2b in the SI). The thermal behavior of [Tl2(μ  12 -1,5-nds)]n (2) after washing the mixture obtained from solid-state mechanochemical reaction (Fig. S2c in the SI) shows that compound 2 with agglomerated nanoparticle morphology is stable up to 335°C. Mass loss between 335 and 410°C which accompanied with a broad exothermic peak may be attributed to combustion of some organic parts of 2 (Fig. S2c in the SI). We also examined thermal behavior of compound 2 after mechanochemical reaction of it with excess KNO3 (Fig. S2d in the SI). The resulting curve was exactly the same as that observed in Fig. S2b (in the SI) which approved that this solid-state cation exchange process is irreversible (Fig. S2d in the SI). Fig. S2e (in the SI) also showed that pure phase of compound 2 nanoparticles, which did not react with KNO3, have similar thermal stability to its other samples obtained from previous steps (Fig. S2b-d in the SI). Thus in addition to powder XRD analyses () and IR spectroscopy (Fig. S1 in the SI), thermogravimetry and differential thermal analyses (TG-DTA) approved that this solid-state mechanochemical exchange is irreversible. The irreversibility of this exchange is due to formation of more stable complex with lower energy in 2 in comparison with 1.

<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="ca0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">XRD patterns; a) simulated pattern based on single crystal data of compound [K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>8</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  A schematic diagram illustrating the solid-state structural transformation of 3D K(I) coordination polymer of 1 (along the crystallographic b axis) to 3D Tl(I) coordination polymer of 2 (along the crystallographic a axis) upon mechanochemical reaction of 1 with TlNO3, (K=blue, Tl=violet, O=red, C=gray, S=yellow and H=white, Tl⋯O short contacts are shown with orange dashed line).
